See some or all of the 33 rooms, stop for an occasional peek out the window over the Arno and Ponte Vecchio, and recharge your batteries at the museum’s newly reopened café above the Loggia dei Lanzi.
The Berlin Panoptikum (Waxworks) opens in 2001, and a stunning, 36-story building, known as The Zoo Window, is being erected.

Exploring its narrow streets, you’ll come upon squares filled with pottery drying in the sun and potters working at their hand-spun wheels, weavers at their looms, and wood-carvers at work on window frames.
Several of the windows show Bible scenes on a majestic scale, but look also for the simple red door above which is written the advice “marry in haste, repent at leisure.”
The original designer, Erwin von Steinbach, began the pink Vosges sandstone façade in 1277, but only got as far as the splendid Gallery of Apostles over the central rose window.
Through the picture windows you can monitor the progress, and the fish, yourselves.
Before you spend your money here, consider that its display windows defaced Casa Lleó Morera, the classic modernista building in which the store is housed.
Li Garden (Liyuan) is composed of arched bridges, gaudy pavilions, open walkways, fish ponds, a miniature pagoda, and a covered walkway with 89 view-framing windows.
The art museum adjoining the Palace of 55 Windows contains a collection of antique thangkas and sculpture in wood and stone.
One of the finest Manueline windows in Portugal is carved in the western wall of the Chapterhouse, encrusted with profusely carved marine motifs.
It is bigger, more prosperous, and more dynamic than any other; its skyline boasts European-style towers; its shop windows and food stalls seize your attention.

In an alley just off the square is the famous Peacock Window of intricately carved wood; the window is part of the Pujari Math, a former priest’s house that now houses the National Woodworking Museum.
